fr:title.text: Soundness of deduction system for regular categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Soundness of deduction system for regular categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The deduction system defined in is sound.

The first two structural rules are given by reflexivity and transitivity in each preorder \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ). The last structural rules is given by the action on morphisms of the functor f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(\Delta )\to \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ).
Every finite conjunction rule is given by the universal properties of terminal objects and binary products.

The first existential quantification rule is given by Frobenius reciprocity proven in . The second existential quantification rule is given by the transposition across the adjunction \exists _{f} \dashv f^{*}.

The first equality rule says the terminal object in \mathsf {Sub}(A) is contained in the equalizer of \mathsf {id}_{A} with itself. Since the equalizer of the identity morphism with itself is an isomorphism (i.e., a maximal subobject of A), the soundness of this rule follows.
For the second equality rule, consider the following pullbacks. The right square is the pullback of \varphi along s.

Since s and t are equalized by the morphism s = t \rightarrowtail \Gamma , the outer square of the following diagram commutes. Thus, the intersection s = t \wedge \varphi {\mathopen {}[s]\mathclose {}} is contained in \varphi {\mathopen {}[t]\mathclose {}}.

Let \mathcal {C} be a category with finite products. A (primitive) doctrine over \mathcal {C} is a \mathcal {C}-indexed category T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT}. If T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT} and U\colon \mathcal {D}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT} are primitive doctrines, then a morphism of doctrines F\colon T\to U consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: A finite-product preserving functor F_{0}\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D}.
For each object X \in \mathcal {C}, a functor F_{1,X}\colon TX\to UF_{0}X.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These data are subject to the condition that for any morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, the following square commutes:

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = TY, ne = {UF_{0}Y}, sw = TX, se = {UF_{0}X}, north = {F_{1,Y}}, south = {F_{1,X}}, west = {Tf}, east = {UF_{0}f}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT} be a doctrine. Suppose that for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits a left adjoint \Sigma _{f}. Then T is said to satisfy Beck-Chevalley condition if, whenever there is a pullback shown below, we have f^{*}\Sigma _{g} \cong \Sigma _{h}k^{*}.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = A, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = B, sw = C, se = D, north = h, south = g, west = k, east = f, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Furthermore, if for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits a right adjoint \Pi _{f}. Then this condition implies that f^{*}\Pi _{g} \cong \Pi _{h}k^{*} by the uniqueness of adjoint.

Let T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT} be a doctrine. Suppose that for each object X \in \mathcal {C}, the fiber T(X) has finite products \wedge and that for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits a left adjoint \Sigma _{f}. Then T is said to satisfy Frobenius reciprocity if for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, objects \varphi \in T(X) and \psi \in T(Y), we have \Sigma _{f}(f^{*}\psi \wedge \varphi ) \cong \psi \wedge \Sigma _{f}(\varphi ).
A (first-order) hyperdoctrine is a doctrine T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT} satisfying the following additional conditions:

fr:ul.fr:li: For each object X \in \mathcal {C}, the fiber T(X) is cartesian closed and has finite coproducts.
For each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits both a left adjoint \Sigma _{f} and a right adjoint \Pi _{f}.
T satisfies Beck-Chevalley.
T satisfies Frobenius reciprocity.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A morphism between hyperdoctrines F\colon T\to U is a morphisms between doctrines satisfying the additional condition that for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, the following squares commute:

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = TX, ne = {UF_{0}X}, sw = TY, se = {UF_{0}Y}, north = {F_{1,X}}, south = {F_{1,Y}}, west = {\Sigma _{f}}, east = {\Sigma _{F_{0}f}}, } \qquad \DiagramSquare { nw = TX, ne = {UF_{0}X}, sw = TY, se = {UF_{0}Y}, north = {F_{1,X}}, south = {F_{1,Y}}, west = {\Pi _{f}}, east = {\Pi _{F_{0}f}}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category with finite limits and T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} be a \mathcal {C}-indexed (pre-)lattice such that

fr:ul.fr:li: For each object X \in \mathcal {C}, the fiber T(X) is cartesian.
For each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits a left adjoint \Sigma _{f}.
Each left adjoint \Sigma _{f} satisfies the Beck-Chevalley condition.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then we can define a naming functor {\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{X}}}\to T(X) for each object X \in \mathcal {C}. Moreover, for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, the following square commutes up to isomorphism.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {{{\mathcal {C}}_{/{Y}}}}, ne = {T(Y)}, sw = {{{\mathcal {C}}_{/{X}}}}, se = {T(X)}, north = {{\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{Y}}, south = {{\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X}}, west = {f^{*}}, east = {T(f)}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For each object f\colon X\to Y in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{Y}}}, take {\mathopen {}[f]\mathclose {}}_{Y} := \Sigma _{f}(1). To extend this assignment to a functor, it suffices to show that whenever there is a morphism \alpha \colon f\to g in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{Y}}}, {\mathopen {}[f]\mathclose {}}_{Y} \leq {\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y} in T(Y).

To this end, note that \alpha ^{*}(1) \leq \alpha ^{*}g^{*}{\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y} in T(X) because the unit of the adjunction \Sigma _{g} \dashv g^{*} gives 1 \leq g^{*}{\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y}. Since \alpha ^{*}, as a right adjoint, preserves terminal objects and f^{*} \cong \alpha ^{*}g^{*} by the (pseudo)functoriality of T, we have 1 \leq f^{*}{\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y}. Then, the transpose along the adjunction \Sigma _{f} \dashv f^{*} yields {\mathopen {}[f]\mathclose {}}_{Y} \leq {\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y}.
Now for each g\colon Z\to Y, form the following pullback:

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = A, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = X, sw = Z, se = Y, north = {f^{*}(g)}, south = g, west = k, east = f, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then by Beck-Chevalley, we have
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {aligned} T(f){\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y} &:= T(f)\Sigma _{g}(1)\\ &\cong \Sigma _{f^{*}(g)}k^{*}(1) && \text {right adjoint preserves terminal object}\\ &\cong \Sigma _{f^{*}(g)}(1)\\ &=: {\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X}f^{*}(g) \end {aligned}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These isomorphisms assemble into a natural isomorphism f^{*}{\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{Y} \cong {\mathopen {}[f^{*}(\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}})]\mathclose {}}_{X} since any two parallel morphisms in the preorder T(X) are equal.

Let T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} be a doctrine with the structures listed in . Then T has comprehension schema if for each object X \in \mathcal {C} the naming functor {\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X} admits a right adjoint {\mathopen {}\{X\colon \mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}\}\mathclose {}}.

fr:title.text: Subobject doctrine of a regular category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subobject doctrine of a regular category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category, then the subobject doctrine \mathsf {Sub}\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} has comprehension schema.

Each fiber \mathsf {Sub}(A) has finite limits inherited from \mathcal {C}. By , each f^{*} has the required left adjoint \exists _{f}. They satisfy the Beck-Chevalley condition because images commute with pullbacks in a regular category. Then by construction the naming functor {\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{X}}}\to \mathsf {Sub}(X) is just \mathsf {Img}, which admits the inclusion functor as a right adjoint.
Fix quantifiers.
Let \mathcal {C} be a sufficiently structured category. We device an (informal) internal language for \mathcal {C} as follows:

fr:ul.fr:li:
Terms:
For any pair of objects \Gamma , \Delta \in \mathcal {C}, we write f, g, h, etc for morphisms \Gamma \to \Delta in \mathcal {C}.
For any pair of composable morphisms f\colon \Delta \to \Xi and x\colon \Gamma \to \Delta , we write f(x) for their composite.
For any pair of morphisms f\colon \Gamma \to \Delta and x\colon \Xi \to \Delta , we write f{\mathopen {}[x]\mathclose {}} for the morphism with codomain \Xi obtained by applying the pullback functor x^{*} to the object f in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{\Delta }}}.

Formulas:
For each object \Gamma \in \mathcal {C}, we write \varphi , \psi , \chi , etc for objects in \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ).
For any two parallel pair of morphisms s,t\colon \Gamma \rightrightarrows \Delta in \mathcal {C}, we write s = t for the equalizer (considered as a subobject of \Gamma ) of s and t.
For any two objects \varphi , \psi \in \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ), we write \varphi \wedge \psi for their intersection.
For any object \Gamma \in \mathcal {C}, we write \top for the terminal object in \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ).
For any object \Gamma \in \mathcal {C}, we write \bot for the initial object in \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ).
For any two objects \varphi , \psi \in \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ), we write \varphi \vee \psi for their union.
For any two objects \varphi , \psi \in \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ), we write \varphi \Rightarrow \psi for their Heyting implication.
For any object \varphi \in \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ), we write \lnot \varphi for its pseudocomplement.
For any object \varphi \in \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ) and morphism f\colon \Gamma \to \Delta , we write \exists _{f}\varphi for the subobject of \Delta obtained by applying the left adjoint \exists _{f} to \varphi .
For any object \varphi \in \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ) and morphism f\colon \Gamma \to \Delta , we write \forall _{f}\varphi for for the subobject of \Delta obtained by applying the right adjoint \forall _{f} to \varphi .
For any object \psi \in \mathsf {Sub}(\Delta ) and morphism f\colon \Gamma \to \Delta , we write \psi {\mathopen {}[f]\mathclose {}} for the subobject of \Gamma obtained by applying the functor f^{*} to \psi .

Contexts: A list x_{1}\colon A_{1},\ldots ,x_{n}\colon A_{n} represents the product A_{1} \times \cdots \times A_{n} in \mathcal {C}. Each variable x_{i} represents the i-th projection \pi _{1}\colon A_{1} \times \cdots \times A_{n}\to A_{i}. If n = 1, then the unique variable x represents the identity morphism.

Sequents: A sequent \Gamma |\varphi \vdash \psi is intended to mean \varphi \leq \psi in the preorder \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ). We say that a sequent \Gamma |\varphi \vdash \psi is satisfied (in \mathcal {C}) if \varphi \leq \psi in \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category.

fr:title.text: Soundness of deduction system for regular categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Soundness of deduction system for regular categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The deduction system defined in is sound.

The first two structural rules are given by reflexivity and transitivity in each preorder \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ). The last structural rules is given by the action on morphisms of the functor f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(\Delta )\to \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ).
Every finite conjunction rule is given by the universal properties of terminal objects and binary products.

The first existential quantification rule is given by Frobenius reciprocity proven in . The second existential quantification rule is given by the transposition across the adjunction \exists _{f} \dashv f^{*}.

The first equality rule says the terminal object in \mathsf {Sub}(A) is contained in the equalizer of \mathsf {id}_{A} with itself. Since the equalizer of the identity morphism with itself is an isomorphism (i.e., a maximal subobject of A), the soundness of this rule follows.
For the second equality rule, consider the following pullbacks. The right square is the pullback of \varphi along s.

Since s and t are equalized by the morphism s = t \rightarrowtail \Gamma , the outer square of the following diagram commutes. Thus, the intersection s = t \wedge \varphi {\mathopen {}[s]\mathclose {}} is contained in \varphi {\mathopen {}[t]\mathclose {}}.
The sequent for functionality seems problematic. Prove the lemma.
Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category and R \in \mathsf {Sub}(A \times B) be a relation satisfying the following sequents:

fr:ul.fr:li: Functional: x\colon A, y\colon B, y'\colon B|R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y') \vdash y = y'
Total: x\colon A|\top \vdash \exists _{y}R

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then there is a unique morphism f\colon A\to B in \mathcal {C} such that x\colon A,y\colon B|R \dashv \vdash f(x) = y is satisfied.
Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category.

Let T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT} be a doctrine. Suppose that for each object X \in \mathcal {C}, the fiber T(X) has finite products \wedge and that for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits a left adjoint \Sigma _{f}. Then T is said to satisfy Frobenius reciprocity if for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, objects \varphi \in T(X) and \psi \in T(Y), we have \Sigma _{f}(f^{*}\psi \wedge \varphi ) \cong \psi \wedge \Sigma _{f}(\varphi ).

Let f\colon A\to B be a morphism in a regular category. Then for any two subobjects A' \rightarrowtail A and B' \rightarrowtail B, we have \exists _{f}(A' \cap f^{*}(B')) \cong \exists _{f}(A') \cap B' in \mathsf {Sub}(B), where \exists _{f} is the left adjoint of f^{*} constructed in .
By the construction of \exists _{f}, this is equivalent to showing the following isomorphism. \mathsf {Img}(f \circ (A' \cap f^{*}(B'))) \cong \mathsf {Img}(f \circ A') \cap B'
Form the following diagram, where the front, left, and right faces are pullbacks.

By the pasting lemma, the back square is also a pullback. Then since covers are stable under pullback in a regular category, the north edge of the back square is also a cover. The diagonal of the right face is \mathsf {Img}(f \circ A') \cap B', which forms a cover-mono factorization of the composite f \circ (A' \cap f^{*}(B')). Thus, by uniqueness, \mathsf {Img}(f \circ (A' \cap f^{*}(B'))) \cong \mathsf {Img}(f \circ A') \cap B' as required.
